A. BACKGROUNDAND STRATEGY
Country background
1. Abundant natural and humanresources enabled Iraqto attain the status o f a middle- income country inthe 1970s. The country developed good infrastructure and well-performing education and healthcare systems, widely regarded as the best inthe MiddleEast. Income per capita rose to over US$3,600 inthe early 1980s. Since that time, successive wars and a repressive, state-dominated economic system have stifled growth and developmentand debilitatedbasic infrastructure and social services. Intemational trade sanctions imposed in 1991took a toll on the economy. Despite the country's rich resource endowment, Iraq's human development indicators are now among the lowest inthe region, andincome per capita dropped to about US$770-1,020 by 2001,with continued decline thereafter. Although there i s a paucity o f reliable economic data, 2003 GDP i s estimated at about US$l3-17 billion, or about US$480-630 per person, assuming a population o f about 26.3 million.
Current Challengesand InternationalResponse
2. Followingthe recent war, Iraq faces enormous challenges, and the situation i s still evolving. Inaddition to a complicated political transition, Iraq needs to rebuildsocial cohesion and implement an economic transition from a centrally-planned economy to a diversified market economy. It will be particularly important to mitigate the temporary adverse effect o f reforms on the poor and vulnerable.
3. A Needs Assessment covering fourteen sectors, preparedjointly bythe World Bank and UnitedNations Development Group (UNDG) andwith the participation o f the Intemational Monetary Fund, estimated that Iraqrequires about US$36 billion over four years, and the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA) estimated separately that Iraq requires about US$l9 billion over four years for areas not coveredby the Needs Assessment, such as security and oil.
4. At anIntemationalDonors' Conference for IraqinMadrid on October 23-24,2003, donors expressed support for the Needs Assessment and pledgedabout US$32 billion for the four-year period covered by the Needs Assessment. Donors also asked the World Bank and UNDGto set up an IntemationalReconstructionFundFacility for Iraqto ensure swift, flexible, and coordinated donor financingfor priority investments consistent with the Need Assessment. The Facility consists o f two trust funds-a World Bank IraqTrust Fundand a UNDGTrust Fund-each with its own intemal governance procedures andwith management structure that ensures close coordination.  2 EducationSector
5. The education system inIraqwas widely regarded as one o f the best inthe Middle East regionuntilthe 1980s. Betweenthe 1960s andthe 1990s, Iraqmade great progress in enrollment at all levels o f education and achieved near universalprimaryenrollment by 1980. For the last decade o f the twentieth century, the system deteriorated seriously as Iraq engaged inthree major conflicts andexperienced over adecade ofinternational sanctions.
6. Primary school enrollment fell to 93 percent in2000, while secondary school enrollment went from 47 percent to 38 percent. More serious, however, was a large drop in attendance. A UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS) reported in2000 that as many as 23 percent o f primary school age children were not attending school, with significantly higher rates among girls and inrural areas. This deterioration created or exacerbated inequities by gender, urban/rural location, andregion. Other sub-sectors, especially technical andvocational education, also experienced stagnation or decline.
7. Quality also declined at all levels o f the education system:teaching and learning conditions deteriorated; teacher quality eroded; curriculum content was distorted or became outdated; and policy and system development came to a standstill. This decline inquality was reflected indeteriorating internal efficiency, made worse by growing poverty. Indeed, poverty emerged as the major cause o f non-attendance, as more o f the direct costs o f provisionwere transferred to households despite the official policy of free education.
8. Behind these developments was a substantial collapse inpublic investment inthe education system. In 1988/1989 the education budget was US$2.5 billion (about 6 percent o f GDP) and expenditure per student was approximately US$620. Over the 1993-2002 period, the annual average expenditure per student stood at approximately US$47, fundedlargely from the Oil-for-Food Program.
9. Duringthe 1990s, textbook provision to schools came under severe financing restrictions; and the previous practice o f issuing a full set o fnew textbooks to every student every year was replaced by a rationing system inwhich textbooks were recycled for two or more years. Duringthe events of April 2003, almost all MOE stores and offices inthe central and southern govemorates were looted and many were burned. A number o f warehouses containing textbooks and paper were also destroyed, along with the government printing ' press inBaghdad, and nearly all master film o f existing textbooks. Textbooks had also come to reflect the curriculum distortions o f the previous regime. As an emergency measure, UNICEF and UNESCO managed the process o f removing the more offensive material inthe textbooks. Financedby USAID and Oil for Food funds, they also managed the printingof textbooks for the 2003/2004 school year, despite considerable operational difficulties experienced as a result o f the bombing o f the UNoffices inAugust 2003. Inthe end around 40% o fneeded textbooks were printedand distributed, although some arrived late inthe school year. For the school year 2004-2005, the M O Erequested that the ITF finance the reprinting anddistribution o f textbooks.
10. The priorities identifiedinthe UNDG/World Bank Joint Needs Assessment represent a national consensus and were endorsed by the Minister o f Education at a meeting inAmman inOctober 2003 attended by senior officials from the Ministry ofEducation (MOE) and from  3 the World Bank, UNICEF, UNESCO, USAID and the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA). These priorities are included inthe MOE Situation Analysis ("Education inIraq: Current Situation andNew Perspectives") o f December 2003.
11. Duringthe AmmanconsultationinOctober 2003, agreement was reachedbetween the MOEand Iraq's major development partners on the following priorities: (i) capacity buildingfor the development ofa strategic framework for the sector, (ii) emergency rehabilitation and supplies (including textbooks), (iii) initiating curriculum reform process, (iv) addressing immediateneeds inteacher training, and (v) initiatingpolicy dialogue on technicalhocational education and training (TVET).
12. The textbook provision activities inthis project were approved by the Iraq Strategic ReviewBoardinFebruary 2004.
13. International experience o f education reform andreconstruction inpost-conflict societies underlines the importance o f quick and visible highimpact activities to address the most urgent system needs backedby intensive capacity buildingfor education authorities. This is necessaryto lay the groundwork for the development o f a comprehensive education strategy aligned with the emergingwider development vision o f the new political authorities. The successful resumption of schooling inIraqinSeptember 2003 was an important achievement. However, the education sector remains fragile, and recent momentum can only be maintained ifthe minimumconditions for leaming are established inschools for the 2004/2005 school year, as part o f a more comprehensive process o f capacity buildingfor wider system reform andmodernization.
B. BANK RESPONSEAND STRATEGY
14. InJanuary 2004, the World Bank's Boardo fExecutive Directors discussed an InterimStrategyNote o fthe World Bank Group for Iraq(Document NumberR2004-0008) and authorized the Bank to act as administrator o f the World Bank IraqTrust Fund(the "WBITF" or "the Trust Fund").
15. The World Bank Group's interimstrategy, which covers the period February-October 2004, focuses on (i) building Iraqi capacity neededurgently for the reconstructionprogram; (ii)preparing and starting to implement. emergency operations to generate employment and restore essential infrastructure and services; and (iii) laying thefoundation for the medium- termprogram, through studies and policy advice.
16. The strategy relies on the World Bank IraqTrust Fundto finance projects, and on Bank budget for economic and sector work and policy advice. The interimwork program includes four proposedprojects amounting to US$400-600 million that will be financed from the Iraq Trust Fundto the extent resources are available (projects will bephased if insufficient resources are available). A multi-sectoral institutional capacity buildingprogram has already commenced. The InterimStrategy originally provided for a single Emergency Education Rehabilitation Project (EERP) that incorporatedthe textbook provision activities inthis project, together with the schoolrehabilitation activities inthe Emergency School RehabilitationProject (ESRP). Inorder to ensure delivery o f textbooks at the start o f the  4 2004-2005 school year, the EERP was split into these two education projects. Other projects under fast-track preparationinclude an emergency community-based rural infrastructure and emergency infrastructure reconstruction. The interimstrategy also includes buildingblocks o f analytical work to support the transition to a diversified market economy and to develop a social protection system. Analytical work has been grouped into three clusters: economic reform and transition; public sector management; andpovertyand safety nets, andtwo sectors (health and education).
17. The Bank was the lead agency for education inthe UNDG/World Bank Joint Needs Assessment, and has worked closely with UNICEF, UNESCO, USAID, and CPA. It i s well positioned to play a leading role inbothrepair and reconstruction and capacity-building for reform. It has considerable accumulated experience insupportinglarge-scale repair and rehabilitation projects inpost-conflict settings. The support for school rehabilitation and textbooks will be complemented by the range o f capacity-building activities inkey policy areas such as educationreform, education management, teacher policy, curriculum development, TVET, and higher education financed initiallythrough a first Capacity BuildingProject.
18. Lessons of Post-Conflict Experience Applied: Basedon the World Bank's recent experience inpost-conflict countries such as East Timor, Bosnia, Algeria, Sierra Leone, West Bank and Gaza, and Kosovo, a number o f important lessons have been leamed and introduced into the design o f the project. First, experience has shown the value of early and visible impact, and the importance o f resumptiono f normal schooling operations to permit the education authorities to focus energy on wider system reform. This project targets that issue directly. A second lesson is the importance o f capacity buildinginthe ministry.This project will be complementedby a range o f capacity-building activities inthe Capacity BuildingProject I. thirdlesson is the importance o fearly and effective collaboration with A other development partners coordinated by the government. The project draws upon the extensive collaborationwith other development partners that have beenactive inIraq, and builds on complementary activities coordinated through the MOE. Finally, becauseo fthe particular difficulties o f implementation and supervision where security conditions make access to the country very difficult, the project draws on experience gained inother similar circumstances, such as Algeria.
C. DETAILED PROJECT DESCRIPTION
Objectives
19. Theprincipal objective o fthe Project is to improve conditions o f leaming inprimary and secondary schools through the urgent provision o fprimary and secondary school textbooks.
Component 1:Provisionof Textbooks (US$39.5 million)
20. The grant will finance the printingand distribution o f about 69 million textbooks for six million students inall governorates, for the school year 2004/2005. This quantity covers over 600 titles for all 12 grades o f the primaryand secondary system. Criteria for the  5 selection o f textbooks to be financed by the grant give the highest priority to primaryand secondary textbooks, with special attentionto final grades o f each phase. Primaryand secondary textbooks have priority over teacher manuals, teacher guides, and vocational and teacher education materials. Annex 5 provides further details on these selection criteria.
21. The M O Ehas provided written assurancethat the textbooks covered bythe grant have beensystematically reviewedby panels o f Iraqi educators and teachers, and material that could give serious offense to other national, ethnic, or religious groups has been removed.
22. The MOE undertook a review inApril o f existing stocks o fpaper to assess quantity and quality. Currently the M O E has in stock between 9,000 and 11,000 tons o fpaper o f acceptable quality purchased under the Oil-for-Food program. This i s sufficient for 25 - 30 milliontextbooks, or approximately 33-40 percent o frequirementsandwill facilitate an early start to printing o f the most urgent textbooks. Printingwill therefore be procured through a combination o fNational Competitive Bidding(NCB) and InternationalCompetitive Bidding (ICB). Printing of textbooks usingthe stocks o fpaper inthe MOE will be procured through NCB. For the remainder o fthe textbooks, ICB will be used, and printerswill be required to obtain the paper as part o f their contracts. Filmfor the printingofbooks will be provided to printersby the MOE.
23. The MOEhas already prepared lists, technical specifications, and schedules o f requirements for ICB andN C B exercises amounting to US$29.38 million (ICB) and US$9.9 million (NCB) covering all the textbooks. Draft biddingdocuments to initiate advance procurement have already been drafted andtendered, so that textbooks can be printedand delivered intime for the opening o f schools inSeptember 2004.
24. Printers will be required intheir contracts (NCB) to collect paper from M O E stores and deliver the books to the govemorates according to the M O E plan, bypassing the central warehouses inBaghdad. While some warehouses were destroyed, adequate warehousing facilities exist inmost govemorates, and where these are inadequate, arrangements will be made to use other facilities such as recreation halls inschools (delivery should take place largely during the school vacation). Further distribution to district distribution centers and schools will be handledby the govemorates using existing procedures, and financedby the MOE. The MOEprepared a detailed distributionplanindicating how andwhenbooks will reach the schools. Allowance has been made inthe attached implementation schedule for possible delays inthe distribution o f textbooks because o fthe highnumber o frisks associated with the project.
25. The grant will also finance technical assistance and training intextbook production, as needed to support efforts by the MOE to ensure that textbooks reflect curriculum development trends and modernintemational standards.

65. This project i s prepared as part o f the Interim Strategy o fthe World Bank to address the urgent reconstructionneeds of Iraq and according to emergency recovery assistance (OP 8.50). Inthe eighties the education system inIraq flourished and compared favourably with the middleincome countries. In 1989,the education budget represented six percent o f GDP and expenditure per  14 student was US$620. However, following three wars and a decade of international trade embargo, expenditure per student dropped to US$47 per year in2002. The resumption of oil exports inIraq andthe reform policies that arebeingintroduced are expected to stimulate sustainable growth over the medium-termandprovide resources for basic social services.

doc.abstracts: The objective of Emergency Textbook Provision Project is to improve conditions of learning in primary and secondary schools in Iraq through the urgent provision of primary and secondary school textbooks. The project has a major component, the provision of textbooks. The grant will finance the printing and distribution of approximately 69 million textbooks for six million students in all governorates, for the school year 2004/2005. This quantity covers over 600 titles for all 12 grades of the primary and secondary system. Criteria for the selection of textbooks to be financed by the grant give the highest priority to primary and secondary textbooks, with special attention to final grades of each phase. The secondary component, project management and capacity building, will finance the basic costs of the Project Management Team (PMT) to manage the project, and the technical assistance and capacity building necessary to ensure effective project management and transfer of skills to the Ministry of Education (MOE).
